snippet.title: CBSE Class 10 | History | Different Sections of Society |
snippet.description:
In this module, you will learn about Different Sections of Society, The rich peasants participated in the Civil Disobedience Movement to protest against revenue, when their demands were not taken up by the Congress they took back their support. Congress was hesitant to support the No –rent campaign of tenants for the fear of alienating the rich peasants. The industrial working class adopted a few Gandhian ideas selectively to support their movements against low wages and poor working condition. The failure of the Second Round table Conference and the growth of socialist ideas in Congress disappointed the business class who had supported the movement. The rich peasant communities such as Patidars of Gujarat and Jats of UP were badly affected by the Economic Depression and the resultant fall in agricultural prices. They demanded the revenue to be waived off but the government refused. Therefore, they joined the Civil Disobedience Movement.
In 1931, the Civil Disobedience Movement was abruptly called off by Mahatma Gandhi
   without any revision of the revenue rates. Consequently, the peasants did not participate in 
   the Civil Disobedience Movement when it was re launched in 1932.
The poor peasants grappled with the problem of paying rent during the time of Depression.
The Congress was uncertain about supporting the poor peasants in their ‘No Rent’ campaign.
    The Congress feared that supporting the tenants could spoil their ties with the Landlords and 
    rich peasants.
Indian business class had reaped huge profits during the First World War. After the war, they 
    wanted to expand their business but the stringent colonial laws were obstructing their way.
To get the business class together, Indian Industrial and Commercial Congress was formed in 
   1920 and the Federation of the Indian Chamber of Commerce and Industries (FICCI) in 1927.
Business class viewed Swaraj as an ideal situation, favourable for the growth of their business,
   a time when all colonial restrictions would be removed.
However, the failure of the Second Round table Conference and the growth of socialist ideas
    in Congress disappointed the business class and made them anxious about the future.
The Industrial working class adopted a few Gandhian ideas such as boycott of Foreign goods as
    part of their own movement against low wages and poor working condition.
The Congress still did not want to include workers’ demands in the movement as they thought
   it would alienate the industrialists.
The Civil Disobedience Movement witnessed mass participation of women. They were
    involved in protests, picketing and boycotts and also helped in manufacturing salt.
On the face of it, Congress encouraged women participation but even Mahatma Gandhi gave
    more importance to the traditional domestic role of women.

snippet.title: CBSE Class 10 | History | Gandhi-Irwin Pact and Round Table Conference |
snippet.description:
In this module, you will learn about Gandhi-Irwin Pact and Round Table Conference, The British Government clamped down on the Congress Leaders and protestors in the Civil 
   Disobedience Movement.
 In 1931, Mahatma Gandhi decided to call off the Civil Disobedience movement and entered
    into a pact with Lord Irwin.
Mahatma Gandhi attended the Round Table Conference but the negotiations failed in the 
   Conference.
Mahatma Gandhi re-launched the Civil Disobedience Movement but by 1934 the movement
   died out.
The British got worried by the growing popularity of the Civil Disobedience movement, so they
   arrested all prominent Congress leaders.
In April1930, Khan Abdul Gaffar Khan, a political and spiritual leader from Peshawar was 
   arrested. His arrest was followed by many demonstrations and protests in Peshawar which was
   suppressed by the British.
The British government dealt with the protestors with an iron hand. Around 10,000 
   Satyagrahis were arrested and small children and women were thrashed by the police.
Mahatma Gandhi decided to call off the Civil Disobedience movement in 1931.
On 5th March 1931, Mahatma Gandhi signed the Irwin Pact and agreed to participate in the 
   Second Round Table Conference to be held in London.
In December 1931, Gandhiji visited London but he came back disheartened as the 
   negotiations did not reach any final decision.
On his arrival in India, Mahatma Gandhi found that several Congress leaders had been 
   arrested and Congress had been declared an illegal party.
Mahatma Gandhi relaunched the Civil Disobedience Movement but by 1934 the movement 
    lost its momentum.

snippet.title: CBSE Class 10 | History | Launch of Non-Cooperation Movement |
snippet.description:
In this module, you will learn about Mahatma Gandhi believed in Swaraj. He suggested that if Indians resolved not to cooperate 
    with the British the British rule would get abolished.
 Mahatma Gandhi proposed a stage by stage by stage strategy for the successful 
    implementation of the Non-cooperation Movement.
After a lot of debates Congress confirmed the Non-cooperation programme during the 
    Nagpur conference in December 1920
Diverse regional groups participated in the Non Cooperation movement to attain Swaraj.
Mahatma Gandhi had suggested in his book Hind Swaraj that if Indians resolved not to 
    cooperate with the British the British rule would get abolished. The fall off the British rule will 
    pave the way for Swaraj or self governance
Mahatma Gandhi realised that the Khilafat movement could be used to unite Muslims and 
    Hindus for the common cause of national movement. 
He decided to launch the Non-cooperation Movement in support of the Khilafat movement. 
He proposed the following stage by stage strategy for the successful implementation of the 
    Non-cooperation Movement:
  Surrender of Government titles, honours and honorary posts by people 
  Boycott of Civil Services, Army, Police, British Courts and Legislative Assemblies School 
   and Colleges and British goods was planned
  Launch of the Civil Disobedience Movement in case of Government suppression
  Mobilisation of popular support
After a lot of debate, Non-cooperation programme was accepted by the Congress during
   the Nagpur conference in December 1920.
In 1921, Non-cooperation- Khilafat Movement began in full force under Mahatma 
   Gandhi’s leadership.

snippet.title: CBSE Class 10 | History | Non-Cooperation Movement in Plantations |
snippet.description:
In this module, you will learn about Non-Cooperation Movement in Plantations, Non-cooperation movement started as a nonviolent resistance of the British rule but over
    the time it became violent. 
The plantation workers ascribed their own meaning to Swaraj and the Non-cooperation 
    Movement.
The plantation workers worked under very strict rules and regulations and were seldom 
    allowed to visit their homes.
Inspired by the Non-cooperation Movement thousands of workers disobeyed the British 
    authorities and left the plantations to go back to their homes.
The workers were caught by the police and beaten mercilessly.
The Non-cooperation Movement was conceptualised as a nonviolent resistance of the British
   rule. However, it developed a violent streak. 
The plantation workers in Assam worked under very strict rules and regulations.
As per the Inland Immigration Act of 1859, the plantation workers were rarely allowed to leave
   to go back to their homes.
Inspired by the Non-Cooperation Movement, thousands of workers left the plantations to go
   back to their homes. 
The journey of the workers was disrupted due and they were police caught by the police and
   beaten up.
The plantation workers had ascribed their own meaning to Swaraj different from that of the
   Congress. They felt that Swaraj marked an era when their sufferings would end.
On 4th February, 1922 thousands of protesters gathered to picket a of the liquor shop at the 
    local market in Chauri Chaura. 
To threaten the protestors, the policemen fired in the air. However the agitated crowd began
   to pelt stones at the police.
The sub inspector ordered fire on the crowd which 3 protestors were killed and several others
   got injured.
The agitated protestors retaliated in a violent manner and began attacking the police from all
    sides.
The policemen got threatened by thousands of people and they locked themselves up in the
    police station.
To avenge the death of the protestors, the frantic crowd set the Police station on fire. In this
   incident 22 policemen were burnt alive, including the station sub inspector.
Shocked by the growing violence, Mahatma Gandhi decided to take back the Non-Cooperation
    Movement in February 1922.

snippet.title: CBSE Class 10 | History | Non-cooperation Movement in Towns and Countryside |
snippet.description:
In this module, you will learn about India-Non-cooperation Movement in Towns and Countryside, The Non-cooperation movement got an active response from all sections of the society. In
    towns, people boycotted British goods and British Institutions.
The movement slowed down in the towns because there were no alternative Indian 
    Institutions solutions to counter the British.
The movement spread to the rural areas where it coincided with the struggle of the
    oppressed peasants and tribal.
The peasants and the tribal movements digressed from Mahatma Gandhi’s ideals and developed a violent streak.
The Non-cooperation-Khilafat Movement began in 1921. Diverse regional groups  
     participated in the movement to fulfil their specific objectives.
Many students, teachers and headmasters and joined the movement. Lawyers also gave 
   up their legal practice and joined in.
Some Indian traders also rejected foreign goods and foreign trade. As a result, the 
   demand for the Indian cloth increased and the vanishing textile industry of India got a 
    new lease of life.
The Non-cooperation movement had begun with an active response from people but it
    slowed down after a while.
Non-cooperation movement spread to the rural areas as well and coincided with the 
    struggle of the oppressed peasants and the tribal.
In Awadh, Baba Ramchandra led the peasant movement. The peasant movement 
    demanded revenue reduction, abolition of beggar and social boycott of oppressive 
    landlords.
In October 1920 Oudh Kisan Sabha was set up headed by Jawaharlal Nehru, Baba and 
   Ramchandra. 
The Peasant movement developed a violent streak. The peasants attacked houses of landlords
    and looted markets leaders misused Gandhiji’s ideals.
In the Gudem Hills of Andhra Pradesh,he tribals had suffered a lot of oppression at the hands
   of the British. 
Under the new forest policy the British Government had imposed a lot of restrictions on tribal.
   They were not allowed to collect fuelwood and  graze their cattle in the forests. British had 
    also forced them to render their services as Begars
The oppressed tribal staged a rebellion under the leadership of a man called Alluri Sitaram 
   Raju.
Raju did not believe in the Gandhian ideals completely. He thought that freedom could be 
    acquired by force and not non-violence.
To achieve Swaraj, the rebels of Gudem hills attacked British officers and carried on Guerilla
    warfare. In 1924, Raju was captured and executed.

snippet.title: CBSE Class 10 | History | Personification of Indian Nationalism |
snippet.description:
In this module, you will learn about Personification of Indian Nationalism, People of different regions of India felt a collective belonging because they had participated
   together in freedom struggles against the common aggressor-The British.
In the 20th century, Indian nation was conceptualised visually as Bharat Mata. Over the years,
   this representation went through a lot of changes.
Revival of the Indian Folklore and reinterpretation of history also contributed to the growth of
    nationalism.
Indians explored glories from the past and viewed the Colonial British era as an opposition to it.
In India, people felt collective belonging because they had fought together in freedom 
    movements against the common aggressor-The British.
Common folklore and songs and popular pictures and symbols also helped in solidifying unity
    and the spirit of nationalism.
The image of Bharat Mata was first created by Bankim Chandra Chattopadhyay. He also wrote
    our national song ‘Vande Mataram’.
Abanindra Nath Tagore created the famous image of Bharat Mata as an ascetic figure. She
   wore saffron coloured clothes and carried chain of beads, cloth, palm leaves and scriptures in  
   her hands. 
The portrayal of Bharat Mata underwent a lot of changes. In the 1905, painting by 
   Abhanindranath tagore Bharat Mata is not portrayed as an ascetic. She is holding a flag and
    standing beside an Elephant and Lion both of which are symbols of power and authority.
Revival of the Indian Folklore was another process which contributed to the growth of 
    nationalism. In the late 19th century, the nationalists began gathering the folk tales.
The Indian tricoloured flag with red green and yellow colour was first designed during the 
    Swadeshi Movement in Bengal.
In 1921, Mahatma Gandhi redesigned the Indian flag with the spinning wheel or Charka at 
    the centre.
The growth of nationalism also happened through the process of reinterpretation of history. 
Indians began exploring glories from their past. They wrote about the ancient times when 
   India was much developed.They saw the Colonial British era an opposition to the Golden 
   years of the past.
The glories of the past and the national symbols such as Bharat Mata were all very Hindu in
    nature. Consequently people of other religions and communities felt alienated.

snippet.title: CBSE Class 10 | History | Rowlatt Act and Jallianwallah Bagh Massacre |
snippet.description:
In this module, you will learn about  India-Rowlatt Act and Jallianwallah Bagh Massacre, In this module you learnt that: 
 Rowlatt Act aimed to curb the political activities in the country and it equipped the courts 
     with the power to detain political prisoners without trial for 2 years.
In opposition to the Rowlatt Act Mahatma Gandhi initiated a civil disobedience movement.
Several people were killed in Jallianwalla Bagh Massacre in Amritsar. This incident had 
    happened under the command of General Dyer.
The Satyagraha Movements by Mahatma Gandhi achieved their desired objectives and were a
   great success.
To control such movements, British proposed the Rowlatt Act in 1919.
Rowlatt Act aimed to curb the political activities in the country and it equipped the courts with
    the power to detain political prisoners without trial for two years.
Mahatma Gandhi opposed the Rowlatt Act by starting a peaceful civil disobedience. He 
   launched a hartal on 6th April 1919.
 The British were threatened that this mass movement could break all lines of communications
     In the country so they decided to suppress the nationalists.
 On 13th April 1919 several villagers had gathered at the Jallianwalla Bagh in Amritsar to 
     attend a cattle fair on the occasion of Baisakhi. 
General Dyer blocked all the entry points to the Jallianwalla Bagh without any without any 
    prior warning, opened fire on the hapless crowd. 
The merciless firing continued for 10-15 minutes and left hundreds of people including 
   women and children dead and wounded.
The Jallianwalla Bagh incident triggered many protests, strikes, and clashes with policemen
    across the cities in North India.
The British Government suppressed these protests and humiliated the Satyagrahis.

snippet.title: CBSE Class 10 | History | Satyagraha - Ideals and Implementation |
snippet.description:
In this module, you will learn about Satyagraha - Ideals and Implementation,
 Satyagraha was a method of mass agitation founded on the sound belief of non-violence as a
     tool of protest.
Mahatma Gandhi knew that India could never match the British in military strength so he
    adopted the concept of Satyagraha.
Mahatma Gandhi successfully organised Satyagraha Movements in Champaran in Bihar, and
    Kheda and Ahmedabad in Gujarat.
Mahatma Gandhi implemented the ideas of non-violence and Satyagraha in India that he had
    tested successfully in South Africa.  
Satyagraha is passive resistance used powerfully to appeal to the conscience of the oppressor. 
 Mahatma Gandhi used the concept of Satyagraha for mass mobilisation and political 
    movements against the injustice of the government. 
In1916, Mahatma Gandhi he visited the poor and miserable peasants of Champaran district in 
    Bihar.
The British used to force the peasants of Champaran to cultivate indigo instead of food crops. 
The villages in Champaran were very unhygienic and affected by social evils like purdah system  
    and untouchability.
Mahatma Gandhi started a drive to improve the infrastructure of villages in Champaran. He 
    also started a Satyagraha movement against the oppression of the peasants.
In 1917, Mahatma Gandhi visited the peasants in the villages of Kheda in Gujarat. People of 
   these villages were also stricken with poverty and social evils.
Mahatma Gandhi along with Sardar Patel garnered mass support and organised a Satyagraha 
    against the tax burden.
Another Satyagaraha movement was organised by Mahatma Gandhi in 1918 to support the 
   demands of the cotton mill workers in Ahmedabad.

snippet.title: CBSE Class 10 | History |The Nationalist Movement of India - An Introduction |
snippet.description:
In this module, you will learn about The Nationalist Movement of India - An Introduction, Rise of nationalism in India was linked with opposition of colonialism. 
The First World War created a new political and economic situation in India.
The Indian freedom movement geared up momentum once again with the coming of 
   Mahatma Gandhi in 1915.
India, the rise of nationalism is intricately linked with the opposition of colonialism.
The revolt or Sepoy Mutiny of 1857 was the first war of Indian independence.
The understanding of common suffering under colonial rule, brought the people of different 
    groups together in their anti-colonial struggle. 
The event which proved instrumental in the history of the Indian Freedom Struggle was the 
    first World War.
Common people were forced to enrol in the forces to fight in the First World War.
During 1918-1919 and then again in1920-21, India was hit by crop failure and shortage of food
    grains. This was followed by famines and outbreak of influenza. 
This harsh social and political situation set the stage for the beginning of nationalist struggle in
    India.
The Indian freedom movement got a new lease of life with the coming of Mahatma Gandhi
   in January 1915.
Mahatma Gandhi had successfully tested novel ideas of non-violence and anti colonial 
   struggle in South Africa. He had fought for the civil 
He motivated people to rise above petty differences of caste, creed, religion, region and
    work single-mindedly towards the common goal of freedom.

snippet.title: CBSE Class 10 | History | New Voices in the Indian Novel |
snippet.description:
In this module, you will learn about New Voices in the Indian Novel, When the printing and circulation of novels increased, several new sections of Indian society got introduced to reading and writing.
Many people thought that reading a novel could have adverse effects on impressionable readers such as women and children.
Women liked novels as it told them stories about women who made choices in relationships and gained some control over their lives.
The earliest writings by women consisted of poems, essays and autobiographical pieces.
In the 20th century, women in South India began to write novels and short stories.
In 1905, Rokeya Hossein, a reformer from Bengal, wrote a feminist short story called Sultana’s Dream about a female utopia.
Indian novels clearly depicted the changing social realities of those times. Indulekha, a Malayalam novel, highlighted the marriage debate between the Nambuthiri Brahmins and the Nayars.
Many people from the suppressed groups like Dalits and peasants began to write. For example, Potheri Kunjambu and Advaita Malla Burman.
Vaikkom Mohammad Bashir was an early Muslim Malayalam writer who dwelt on personal experience and wrote short stories and novels.

snippet.title: CBSE Class 10 | History | Novels in the Colonial World |
snippet.description:
In this module, you will learn about Novels in the Colonial World, Novels developed in the Europe during the 17th and 18th centuries, at a time when it was colonising the world.
Early English novels like Robinson Crusoe projected the western world as superior and colonised nations as primitive.
Writing novels allowed Indian writers to explore their identities and problems. Many Indian novels criticised the defects in society and suggested reforms.
Novels were used by British administrators to gather information on the social and religious life of Indians.
Colonial historians showed Indians as weak, and dependent on the British. Indian writers wrote novels to glorify Indian history and create a sense of national pride in people.
Premchand depicted collective belonging in his novels by showing characters from all strata of society.
Novels created a sense of collective belonging as they were read by people from all walks of life who shared the same language.
Novels like Indulekha showed how Indian readers could successfully blend western and Indian lifestyles. 
The novel favoured the growth of silent reading.

snippet.title: CBSE Class 10 | History | Rise of the Novel in India |
snippet.description:
In this module, you will learn about Rise of the Novel in India, Historically, Indian stories in prose had been written in Sanskrit, and ‘dastan’ in Urdu and Persian. However, none of these texts were like the modern novel.
The growth of the reading public, print and vernaculars proved favourable for the growth of the novel in India in the 19th century.
One of the first Marathi novels was Yamuna Paryatan by Baba Padmanji about the miserable life of widows. 
The first novel in Bengali was Karuna O Phulmonir Bibaran written by Hannah Mullens in 1852.
In northern India, famous Hindi writer Bhartendu Harishchandra motivated many poets and writers in his circle to translate novels from other languages.
The first Hindi novel was Pariksha Guru written by Srinivas Das, which popularised the use of Hindi and the Devanagri script.
In southern India, writers like Chandu Menon and Kandukuri Viresinlingam tried to translate English novels into Indian languages.

In 1889, Indulekha, the first Malayalam novel by Chandu Menon, was published. 
In Bengal, the novels were based on historical events or the inner world of domestic life.
The Indian novel brought together people from different backgrounds and infused a sense of shared community in them.

snippet.title: CBSE Class 10 | History | Rise of the Novel |
snippet.description:
In this module, you will learn about Rise of the Novel, The novel is a narrative form that captivates readers and transposes them into an imaginary world of fictitious characters.
The wide circulation of printed copies and circulating libraries made the novel a popular genre with people across different strata of society.
Novels allow the reader a private reading experience as well as the joy of public reading.
The first novels were written in the 17th century, but novel writing blossomed in the 18th century.
Novel writers experimented with different styles, for example, epistolary and serialised novel.
Novels were about everyday lives of ordinary people. Charles Dickens’ novels talked about England during industrialisation.
In The Mayor of Casterbridge, Thomas Hardy depicted the fast vanishing rural world.
The novel blended the spoken language and the classical language, and brought different people on a common platform.
The rise of novels also witnessed the active involvement of women as writers and readers.
The novels of Jane Austen and Charlotte Bronte depicted the world of women, and dealt with the themes of courtship, marriage and money. 
Writing was not considered an ideal profession for women, so women writers used false name or pseudonyms.
Novels for young boys aroused the adventure of visiting and conquering new lands. For example, R. L. Stevenson’s Treasure Island and Rudyard Kipling’s The Jungle Book.

snippet.title: CBSE Class 10 | History | Changes in the Nineteenth Century |
snippet.description:
In this module, you will learn about Changes in the Nineteenth Century, You have now reached the end of the module on Changes in the Nineteenth Century. 
In this module, you learned that:
In the nineteenth century, children, women and workers became a part of the reading culture.
Publishers printed textbooks, folktales and fairy tales for the children.
Women took up reading and writing. Some of them included: Jane Austen, the Bronte sisters and Mary Ann Evans.
Printers and publishers came up with new strategies to sell their products.
A series of innovations took place in the printing technology.

snippet.title: CBSE Class 10 | History | India and the World of Print |
snippet.description:
In this module, you will learn about India and the World of Print, The Portuguese missionaries introduced printing press in India.
James Augustus Hickey published the first English language weekly newspaper the Bengal Gazette.
Towards the end of eighteenth century, a number of newspapers and journals were published.
Print and newspapers became useful medium to convey the views and thoughts across people.
Men and women writers wrote about issues related to women and on caste discrimination and 
People read stories, poems, as well as social and political issues.

snippet.title: CBSE Class 10 | History | Print and Censorship |
snippet.description:
In this module, you will learn about Print and Censorship, Print had a huge impact on its reader and so the Company wanted to restrict the publications.
In the 1820s, the Calcutta Supreme Court passed certain regulations to control press freedom.
After the revolt of 1857, some Englishmen demanded to clamp the local press and control the spread of nationalism.
The Vernacular Press Act was passed in 1878 which regulated the vernacular presses.
Any attempt by the company to suppress nationalist expression would lead to militant.

snippet.title: CBSE Class 10 | History | Print Revolution and Its Impact |
snippet.description:
In this module, you will learn about Print Revolution and Its Impact, People used the print technology to freely spread their ideas which put fear on those in authority. 
One such religious debate in 1517, by Martin Luther led to the Protestant Reformation in Europe.
To prevent rise of dissenting ideas, the Roman Church imposed limitations and began to maintain an Index of Prohibited Books from 1558.
As the reading culture bloomed, booksellers printed various books.
People believed that books had power to liberate society from despotism.

snippet.title: CBSE Class 10 | History | The Advent of Print Technology |
snippet.description:
In this module, you will learn about The Advent of Print Technology, In this module, you learned:
The hand printing technology was first developed in China, Japan and Korea.
In AD 868, the Japanese printed their first book ─ Diamond Sutra.
In Japan, Kitagawa Utamaro introduced an interesting art form called ukiyo.
In the thirteenth century, the hand-printing technology was introduced in Europe via the silk route.
In 1430s, Johann Gutenberg, a German invented the printing press.

snippet.title: CBSE Class 10 | History | Before the Industrial Revolution |
snippet.description:
In this module, you will learn about Before the Industrial Revolution, Industrialisation did not exactly begin with industries and machines.
The early industrialisation phase, also known as proto industrialisation, paved the way for modern industrial economies.
In the 17th and 18th centuries, several merchants in Europe shifted their production to the countryside. They persuaded peasants and artisans to produce for an international market.
The proto industrial times involved a lot of workers who were working from the countryside and not factories.
By the 1730s, factories began developing in Britain, but they actually expanded in the late 18th century.
The invention of the cloth mill by Richard Arkwright brought a revolution in cloth production by bringing together the scattered processes under one single roof.
The railway network expanded in Britain as well as in the colonies, and there was a huge demand for iron and steel.
Even at the end of the 19th century, most textile production happened through domestic units.
Industrialists were still hesitant about the new machines due to their high repair and maintenance cost, so the shift to machines was a gradual and slow process.

snippet.title: CBSE Class 10 | History | Factories in India |
snippet.description:
In this module, you will learn about Factories in India, Indians got involved in the British China trade by providing finance, procuring supplies and shipping consignments.
After making money from the China trade, some Indians decided to set up their own industries.
In Bengal, Dwarkanath Tagore invested his money to set up six joint stock companies in the 1830s and 1840s, but they did not flourish. 
Jamsetjee Nasserwanji Tata and Dinshaw Petit established industries in Bombay, while Seth Hukumchand set up the first jute mill in Calcutta.
The stringent policies of the British government restricted their trade. Their exports were limited to items that were required by the British.
European managing agencies were given the task of controlling Indian industries. 
In the second half of the 19th century, Indian industries multiplied.
The factories opened new avenues of employment by hiring people as labourers.
As the number of job aspirants increased, mill owners began to hire a jobber who helped manage recruitment.

snippet.title: CBSE Class 10 | History | Hand Labour and New Technology |
snippet.description:
In this module, you will learn about Hand Labour and New Technology, During the 19th century, many people migrated to the industrial centres in search of jobs.
Since the market was flooded with people, labour was cheap.
The owners of seasonal industries preferred to hire manual labour for a smaller period than installing machines.
Manual work was favoured for products that required intricate design and finish.
Workers had to spend weeks of extreme hardship before they finally got jobs.
During the 19th century, wages increased slightly, but their real value remained low due to the consequent price rise.
Till the mid-19th century, nearly 10 percent of the urban population was very poor.
There was a dramatic rise in the unemployed population in the cities during the slump.
In the second half of the 19th century, building activities employed many people.

snippet.title: CBSE Class 10 | History | Industrialisation-Industrialisation in Colonies |
snippet.description:
In this module, you will learn about Historically, India has been known world over for its flowing silks and crisp cottons. Textiles were one of the most vital industries of India.
The old sea ports of Surat, Masulipatam and Hooghly also enhanced the textile trade, and connected India with the Gulf, ports of the Red Sea and that of South-East Asia.
Indian merchants and bankers played a key role in this network of export trade. 
European companies obtained several concessions from local courts and secured monopoly rights to trade.
Old Indian ports shrank, and Bombay and Calcutta emerged as the new ports catering to European companies.
After establishing its power, the East India Company developed a system of management and control to eradicate competition, control costs and ensure regular supply of textile goods.
The East India Company also appointed a paid servant, called the Gomastha, who supervised the weavers, collected their produce and examined the quality of cloth.
The Gomasthas were insensitive to the weavers. Moreover, the prices paid to the weavers were also low.
Due to the exploitation, some weavers rebelled, while some migrated to other villages. Some of them became agricultural labourers.
With the arrival of goods from Manchester, the weavers faced stiff competition in the local markets. Due to the import duties overseas, Indian weavers lost their overseas market as well.
During the US Civil War, Britain turned to India for raw cotton, which led to an increase in cotton prices.
Towards the end of the 19th century, India saw the growth of factories, and the fine art of weaving died a slow death.

snippet.title: CBSE Class 10 | History | Marketing and Industrial Growth |
snippet.description:
In the last phase of the 19th century, Indian markets were flooded by goods from Britain.
British manufacturers used effective advertisements to create a positive image of their product and boost sales.
Early Manchester labels showed many Indian Gods and Goddesses to create respect and approval for the product.
The advertisements by Indian manufacturers were very nationalistic in nature.
During the Swadeshi Movement, Indian industrial groups pressurised the government to increase tariff protection and grant them concessions.
During the World War I, supply of Manchester goods declined so Indian industries got a chance to expand in the home market.
Indian industries were also used to supply items for the British army in war.
After the war, British economy could not compete with new players US, Japan and Germany and collapsed. Manchester could not regain its position in the Indian market either.
The handloom cloth production increased in the 20th century due to the use of looms with fly shuttle. The weavers learnt to survive the cut throat competition from the mills.
After World War I, many factories grew in India but the maximum labour force worked out of small household units in the villages.

snippet.title: CBSE Class 10 | History | Growth of the World Economy After World War II |
snippet.description:
In this module, you learn about, The post war years were marked with a lot of social, political and economic instability.
The post war economic system aimed at maintaining economic stability and full employment.
The Bretton Woods conference established the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank.
The developing countries collectively formed a group known as G-77 to boost their growth.
The New International Economic Order was formed to control their natural resources and get better trade opportunities.
In the last years of nineteen seventies, multinational companies shifted their business operations to countries such as India, China, and Brazil.

snippet.title: CBSE Class 10 | History | Impacts of Colonialism on Economy and People |
snippet.description:
In this module, you learn about, Impacts of Colonialism on Economy and People, In the nineteenth century, world trade expanded and Europeans began to colonise Africa.
Europeans wanted to get cheap raw material and labour from Africa.
Africa had a relatively small population that never worked for wages. People had enough land and livestock to sustain them.
The Europeans wanted to employ people in the mines and plantations so they imposed heavy taxes and inheritance laws on Africans.
An important event that led to the complete submission of natives was the outbreak of Rinderpest, adeadly cattle disease.
Colonial rulers manipulated the outbreak of rider pest in Africa to subdue the native population and force them to work for wages.
The carving of Africa was formally completed in eighteen eighty five in Berlin.

snippet.title: CBSE Class 10 | History | Indian Indentured Labour and Indian Trade |
snippet.description:
In this module, you learn about, Indian Indentured Labour and Indian Trade, One of the important developments in the 19th century was the migration of labour from China and India.
In India people migrated as indentured labourers from present day regions of eastern Uttar Pradesh, Bihar, Central India, and parts of Tamil Nadu.
Indian Indentured labourers worked in Caribbean islands, Mauritius, Fiji, Sri Lanka, Malaya and tea plantations of Assam.
The Indentured labourers were hired by way of a contract which promised that the workers could return to India after they had served their employer for five years.
The living conditions for the indentured labourers used to be very cruel.
Indentured labourers developed their own forms of self expression which was actually a blend of Indian and foreign cultural forms.
Indentured labour migration was extremely criticised and finally abolished in 1921.
In India, the peasants borrowed from local bankers such as Shikaripuri Shroffs and Nattukottai Chettiars. These bankers financed export agriculture in Central and South East Asia.
In the 19th century, the value of British exports to India was much higher than the British imports to India.
Britain maintained a trade surplus with India which helped it balance out its trade deficits with other countries

snippet.title: CBSE Class 10 | History | Shaping of the World Economy |
snippet.description:
In this module, you learn about, Shaping of the World Economy, In the 19th century, technological, social, economic and political changes shaped the world economy.
In the 19th century, three flows governed the international economic exchanges. Flow of trade, flow of labour and movement of capital.
In the late 18th century in Britain, due to the increase in population the demand for food grains had also increased considerably.
British government also imposed Corn Laws which restricted the import of corn in Britain. 
Corn Laws were abolished after it faced criticism from people. Thereafter, witnessed a deluge of cheap imported food which impacted agriculture.
In Britain, people migrated to cities and other countries in search of jobs and better life.
In Russia, Australia and America, new means of transport were developed to boost trade. New settlements were built and accommodate emigrant labourers.
Technological innovations also helped in the expansion of trade. In New Zealand, America and Australia refrigerated ships were used to carry perishable items such as meat to Britain.

snippet.title: CBSE Class 10 | History | The Great Economic Depression |
snippet.description:
In this module, you learn about, The Great Economic Depression, The Great Depression began in 1929 with the crashing of the New York Stock Exchange and continued well into the mid nineteen thirties.
During the Depression, agricultural prices crashed, industrial production came to a halt, and millions of people became jobless and 
homeless.
The depression was caused due to an overflow of food grains in the market which led to a fall in the agricultural prices.
During and after the war US had emerged as an international money lender.
US withdrew loans from other countries because of which major banks and currencies collapsed in Europe.
During the Depression, India’s exports and imports shrunk to almost half. The agricultural prices fell and affected the peasants and farmers badly.
The poor peasants mortgaged their land, jewellery and other precious things to pay off debts and meet their daily needs.
The depression did not affect the middle class urban Indian. Due fall in prices all commodities began to cost less.
The British Government provided tariff protection to industries there was also an increase in industry investment.

snippet.title: CBSE Class 10 | History | World Economy Before and After World War 1 |
snippet.description:
In this module, you learn about, World Economy Before and After World War 1, World trade and world economy suffered a huge jolt due to World War I.
It was fought between two opposing groups known as Triple Allies and Triple Entente.
World war one can technically be called the first modern industrial war.
Years after the war were marked with a lot of social, political and economic instability.
A huge chunk of working class men was completely wiped off in Europe during World War I.
Since the men were at the battle front women were recruited to do the jobs which were only reserved for men earlier.
The recovery period after the war was difficult and long drawn. Britain found it hard to regain its dominant position in the world economy.
US recovered effectively after World War one was the US. It had lent financial help to other countries during the war so it emerged as an international creditor.
After nineteen twenty, the US economy grew at a rapid pace courtesy mass production.
The owner of Ford Motor Company, Henry Ford championed the assembly line method of mass production to produce vehicles at a faster rate.
The US economy saw arise in the wages of workers and a consequent rise in the consumption of consumer goods.
The demand for consumer goods was also fuelled by the boom in the housing and construction sector. Houses were available on loan.
Overall, the nineteen twenties turned out to be a golden era for the US economy.

snippet.title: CBSE Class 10 | History | Beginning of Colonialism in Vietnam |
snippet.description:
In this module, you learn about, Beginning of Colonialism in Vietnam, The French colonised Vietnam and used its natural resources to meet their business needs.
 Policy maker Paul Bernard felt that the main motive behind acquiring colonies was to make profits and so, it was important to develop the economy of the colony.
Colonialism is a process of building and maintaining of colonies in one territory by people from another territory and exploiting it economically.
Vietnam, Cambodia and Laos were referred to as Indo-China.
Trade had flourished in Old Vietnam and it was linked with the maritime silk route.
The French arrived in Vietnam in 1858 and consolidated their hold over the northern region by mid 1880.
Franco Indo-China was formed in 1887.
Writer and policy-maker, Paul Bernard believed that the prime motive behind acquiring colonies was to flourish business and make profits.  
The French colonization and their growing dominance in the country created tremendous unrest in Vietnam and resulted in nationalist resistance.
Colonialism – A  process of building and maintaining of colonies in one territory by people from another territory and exploiting it economically.
Indentured labour – A form of labour where labourers worked on the basis of contracts that did not specify any rights of labourers but gave immense power to employers.

snippet.title: CBSE Class 10 | History | Civilising Mission in Vietnam - Education |
snippet.description:
In this module, you learn about, Civilising Mission in Vietnam - Education, The French used education as a tool to carry out civilising mission in Vietnam.
The new French schools glorified France and looked down upon Vietnamese and their customs.
The domination of French culture faced opposition and    resistance in Vietnam.The French used education as an important tool to carry out
    their civilising mission. 
  The French citizens in Vietnam called Colons felt that educated
    Vietnamese could replace them as teachers, shopkeepers and
    policemen.
 The Vietnamese elite were influenced by the Chinese
  culture and so, the traditional education system was 
  dismantled and the new French education system was 
  introduced.
  The school textbooks glorified and justified French colonial   rule and portrayed the Vietnamese as primitive, and incapable of intellectual work.
  The Tonkin Free School was started in 1907 to provide 
    western education. It promoted western ideas as well as 
    western styles.
 By 1920s students formed various political parties such as
    the Party of Young Annan and they published nationalist
     journals like Annanese Student.

snippet.title: CBSE Class 10 | History | Contribution of Women and the End of Vietnam War |
snippet.description:
In this module, you learn about, Contribution of Women and the End of Vietnam War, The stories of rebel women from past like Trieu Au and the Trung sisters were used to create nationalism in Vietnam.
Women played a crucial role in the Vietnam War.
Women actively participated in the resistance movement and acted as nurses and helped in constructing underground rooms and tunnels.
 70 to 80% of the total youth workers on the Ho Chi Minh Trail were women.
The war received a lot of criticism in US as thousands of soldiers had been killed on either side.
 Widespread criticism of, war and US Government policies paved the way for negotiations. In July 1974, a peace settlement was signed in Paris.
 Vietnam got unified on 13th April 1975.
Vietnamese women played a crucial role during the war and in other anti-imperialist  movements in Vietnam.
 Trung Sisters and Trieu Au are famous women warriors of the ancient times.
Popular literature and thinkers celebrated the women icons who had broken away from the traditional social mould.
 Women carried thousands of kilograms of cargo weapons and food and guarded important key points on Ho Chi Minh Trail. 
 Between 1965- 1975 women formed seventy to eighty percent of the total youth workers on the Ho Chi Minh trail.
 The war received a lot of criticism in US as thousands of soldiers had been killed on either side. 
 Writers such as Mary McCarthy and actor Jane Fonda visited Vietnam and brought the Vietnamese struggle to the notice of international community.
 Widespread criticism of, war and US Government policies paved the way for negotiations. In July 1974, a peace settlement was signed in Paris.
The North Liberation Front occupied the Presidential Palace in Saigon on 30th April, 1975 and unified Vietnam.

snippet.title: CBSE Class 10 | History | Entry of the US into the Vietnam War |
snippet.description:
In this module, you learn about, Entry of the US into the Vietnam War, US had entered the war in order to help the French and combat the growth of
   Communism.
US used chemical weapons that have its effects till today. 
There were both supporters and critics of the war
 The Vietnamese utilised their limited resources to the maximum in the war, The Ho Chi Minh Trail is one such example
Communism was on a rise in North Vietnam under the leadership of Ho Chi Minh.
North Vietnam helped the NLF of South Vietnam to overthrow the dictatorial rule of Ngo Dihn Diem. They also decided to overlook the terms of the Geneva Conference and unify Vietnam.
The spread of Communism was viewed as a potential threat by the capitalist nations especially  the US. 
 US sent in their troops to South Vietnam to intervene and this was the start of the catastrophic US Vietnam war.
  Weapons such as B52s Agent Orange, Napalm and Phosphorous Bombs destroyed many villages and razed down forests.
 The US decision to intervene in Vietnam was criticized vehemently back home.
 Despite the advanced technology and excellent medical facilities, the US suffered a lot of causalities in the war.
 The Vietnamese used their limited resources to gain maximum advantage. The Ho Chin Minh Trail is an example in point.
 This trail was a massive network of footpaths and roads, used to transport men and materials from the north Vietnam to south Vietnam. 
 The US regularly bombed the trail to disrupt supplies, but these attempts failed miserably as the trail was quickly rebuild.

snippet.title: CBSE Class 10 | History | French Vision of Modernisation - A Complete Failure |
snippet.description:
In this module, you learn about, French Vision of Modernisation - A Complete Failure, Some Vietnamese intellectuals were in favour of strengthening Vietnamese
   traditions.
Other group of intellectuals wanted to imbibe the best from the west even 
    while opposing their domination.
By the end of the 19th century, Phan Boi Chau emerged as a prominent 
   Confucian nationalist.
Another nationalist Phan Chu Trinh, accepted the French ideal of liberty but
    accused the French for not abiding by the ideal.
Japan and China provided models for change and served as a refuge for the
    people of Vietnam.
One group of intellectuals was in favour of strengthening Vietnamese traditions in order to
    resist western domination.
The other group felt that Vietnam could imbibe the best from the west even while opposing
    their domination.
One of the most prominent Confucian nationalist was Phan Boi Chau.
 Phan Boi Chau formed the Revolutionary Society, Duy Tan Hoi in1903. 
 Phan Chu Trinh differed in opinion with Phan Boi Chau. 
  Phan Chu Trinh accepted the French revolutionary ideal of liberty but accused the French 
   for not abiding by the ideal.
  Japan and China also became the centre for revolutionaries to build their network 
   comprising of other Asian revolutionaries.
  The students wanted to drive out the French from Vietnam, overthrow the puppet emperor
    and re-establish the deposed Nguyen dynasty.
 The objective of the revolutionaries was no longer to set up a constitutional monarchy
   but to establish a Democratic Republic in Vietnam.

snippet.title: CBSE Class 10 | History | Health and Hygiene - Colony Versus Empire |
snippet.description:
In this module, you learn about, Health and Hygiene - Colony Versus Empire -The sewers of modern Hanoi became a favourable 
   place for the breeding of rats and growth of the 
   bubonic plague.
The French used a bounty programme for rat catching and paid goo bounty for each rat that was caught.
Vietnamese realised the concept of collective bargaining and manipulated the French to their advantage.
 The rat hunt marked the defeat of French colonisers
   and an utter failure of their civilising mission.
In 1903, the bubonic plague broke out in Hanoi and people 
    manipulated the situation in a different way to exploit French
    colonisers.
 Modernizing Hanoi, one of the main cities of Vietnam came first
    on their agenda.
 The French part of Hanoi was beautified with wide avenues and 
    a well laid out sewer system whereas the native quarter was
    completely ignored with no modern hygienic facilities.
 The sewers constructed in the French part of the city provided 
    perfect conditions for rats to breed in.
To combat the rat menace, a rat hunt was started in 1902
 While catching rats in the dirty sewers, the Vietnamese 
    realised the concept of collective bargaining.
 The bubonic plague continued to affect Hanoi during 1903 and
    the subsequent years. 
  The Rat Hunt marked the defeat of French colonisers and an 
   utter failure of their civilising mission.

snippet.title: CBSE Class 10 | History | Religion and Anti Colonialism |
snippet.description:
In this module, you learn about, Religion and Anti Colonialism, Religion played an important role in strengthening  colonial control, and it also provided ways of  resistance.
 Catholic Missionaries set up by the French successfully converted people to Christianity in Vietnam. 
 Conversions led to serious objections from all quarters, the Scholars Revolt of 1868 was one such example
 Another movement against the French was the Hoa Hao movement started in nineteen thirty nine by Huynh Phu So
 In the 18th century, there were significant movements against the cultural attack of  the French in Vietnam.
Vietnam was a place for many religions such as Confucianism, Buddhism and local practices.
The elites in Vietnam were educated in Chinese and Confucianism.
The peasantry in Vietnam believed in a variety of syncretic traditions that combined Buddhism and local beliefs.
The French missionaries had introduced Christianity in Vietnam.
18th century was marked by significant religious movements which were engineered by different sections of society against this cultural attack of the French.
Scholars Revolt of 1868 was a protest against French rule and the spread of Christianity
 Hoa Hao was one such movement against the French which started in nineteen thirty nine and became a rage in the Mekong Delta. The man behind this movement was Huynh Phu So.
 Huynh Phu So was sent to a mental asylum and later he and his followers exiled to a concentration  camp
 Overall, religious movements had a contradictory relationship with mainstream nationalism.
The religious movements were successful in provoking anti-imperialist sentiments.

snippet.title: CBSE Class 10 | History | Vietnamese Nationalism - In the Light of Communism |
snippet.description:
In this module, you learn about, Vietnamese Nationalism - In the Light of Communism, In February 1930, Ho Chi Minh a famous Vietnamese communist revolutionary came forward to  bring together the competing nationalist groups in Vietnam 
The Democratic Republic of Vietnam was formed and Ho Chi Minh became its Chairman.
The French tried to gain control by using Bao Dai as the puppet king of Vietnam.
After 8 years of fighting, the Vietminh defeated French in Dien Bien Phu in 1954. 
After the Geneva peace negotiations, Vietnam was divided into two parts , North and South Vietnam.
Ho Chi Minh and the communists took control of the north Vietnam while Bao Dai’s regime was to look after the south Vietnam.
NLF of South Vietnam fought for the unification of the country with the help of the Ho Chi Minh government in the North Vietnam and
Threatened by the rise of communism in Vietnam and the adjoining countries, US sent its troops to intervene in the developing situation.
In February 1930, Ho Chi Minh a famous Vietnamese communist revolutionary  established the Vietnamese Communist party also known as Vietnam Cong San Dang. 
 In 1940, Japan occupied Vietnam in order to make imperial gains in Southeast Asia.
 The League for the Independence of Vietnam also known as the Vietminh fought with Japan
   and recaptured Hanoi in September in 1945.
 The Democratic Republic of Vietnam was formed and Ho Chi Minh became its Chairman
 Battle of Dien Bien Phu convinced the Vietnamese in their ability to fight and strategic 
  planning.
After the French defeat, the peace negotiations took place in Geneva and Vietnam was 
   divided into two parts; north and south Vietnam.
 Ho Chi Minh and the communists took control of the north Vietnam while Bao Dai’s regime was to look after the south Vietnam.
 In South Vietnam The Bao Dai regime was soon overthrown by a coup led by Ngo Dinh
    Diem, an authoritarian.
The opposition got united as National Liberation Front or NLF and resisted Ngo Dinh Diem’s
    dictatorial rule. 
 NLF fought for the unification of the country with the help of the Ho Chi Minh government in the north.
Threatened by the rise of communism in Vietnam and the adjoining countries, US sent its
   troops to intervene in the developing situation.

snippet.title: CBSE Class 10 | History | Advent of Liberalism in Europe |
snippet.description:
In this module, you learn about, Advent of Liberalism in Europe, during the mid-18th century, Europe was divided into small kingdoms and principalities. 
The concept of nation states did not exist at all. People with diverse ethnic groups lived in eastern and central Europe.
Some of the prominent empires in Europe at this time were the Ottoman Empire and the Habsburg Empire.
People residing in the Habsburg Empire spoke different dialects and did not share a collective past. 
The ethnic diversity in Europe provided a ready ground for the growth of nationalistic ideas inspired by the French Revolution.
During the 19th century, the landed aristocracy was a small but influential class in Europe.
Members of the aristocracy in Europe were connected to each other because of their similar way of life and inter-marriages.
Aristocrats owned large estates in the country side and town houses.
French was a common language spoken by the aristocracy for diplomacy and high society.
A majority of the European population was made up of peasants.
In the late eighteenth and nineteenth centuries, new social groups came into existence. They were:
Working class
Middle class
The middle class was characterised by its free-thinking liberal mindset.
The middle class wanted the end of autocratic rule and form a people’s government.
The word liberalism traces its roots from the Latin word ‘liber,’ meaning freedom. The concept of liberalism was born in the middle class.
The middle class believed in the need for freedom and equality of all individuals before law.
Although liberalism popularised the idea of a people’s government, the right to vote or suffrage was not extended to all citizens.
In France, women were given the status of a minor and subjugated to the authority of men.
Throughout the 19th and early 20th centuries, women and non-propertied men organised protests and movements demanding equal rights.
Liberalism implied freedom of markets, and unrestricted movement of goods and capital.
The Napoleonic Code, though revolutionary for its time, was not able to address the growing needs of the industrialists.
In 1834, a customs union or ‘Zollverein` was formed at the initiative of Prussia and joined by most of the German states.
This union eliminated tariff barriers and reduced the number of currencies from over 30 to 2.
A railway network was also formed which enhanced mobility and communication.

snippet.title: CBSE Class 10 | History | Age of Revolutions [1830 To 1848] |
snippet.description:
In this module, you learn about, Age of Revolutions [1830 To 1848], The period between1830 and 1848 was marked by a lot of uprisings and revolutions in Europe.
Europe saw a series of revolutions in Italy, Germany, Poland, Turkey and Ireland.
In 1830, the Bourbon dynasty was overthrown by the revolutionaries in France. This event is known as the July Revolution.
Inspired by the July Revolution, Belgium broke away from the United kingdom of the Netherlands.
In1821, the Greek war of independence triggered nationalist feelings in Europeans.
Several poets (Lord Byron) and artists supported the Greek war against the Ottoman Empire.
In the 19th century, art and literature helped in creating the idea of nation.
After the French revolution, there was rise of a literary and cultural movement called romanticism, which sought to develop nationalist sentiment.
This national sentiment was mobilised by artists by using the common language, or vernacular, and popular folk arts that people understood and identified with.
Writers, poets and painters of the romantic era stressed on individualism, nationalism, feeling, and emotion as opposed to reason and science.
German romantic philosopher Johann Gottfried Herder stressed that true German culture could be found in folklore and folk art of the common people.
In Poland, nationalist feelings were kept alive through music and language.
As a mark of protest, the Polish language was used in church gatherings and religious instruction by the clergy in Poland.
The Grimm brothers collected German folktales and popularised German.
The year after 1830 saw a lot of hunger and hardship in Europe.
In the first half of the 19th century, the population of Europe had increased a lot.
Many people migrated from the rural areas to the growing slums in the cities.
Small producers in towns faced stiff competition from cheap machine made-goods in England.
In certain regions of Europe, aristocracy and feudalism still prevailed.
In 1835, Silesian weavers revolted against their contractors.
In 1848, a food shortage led to the peasant uprising in France.

snippet.title: CBSE Class 10 | History | The Rise of Nationalism in Europe-French Revolution |
snippet.description:
In this module, you learn about, french Revolution, The French Revolution was an influential event that marked the age of revolutions in Europe.
The revolutionaries referred to France as la patrie or the fatherland, where all citizens or le citoyen enjoyed equal rights under the constitution.
The revolutionaries tried to establish a collective French identity for the people by adopting French flag, composing nationalistic songs and hymns, discouraging the use of regional dialects and adopting French as the common language of France.
Administrative changes after the revolution
A body of active citizens elected the Estates General and renamed it as the National Assembly. 
A centralised administrative system was formed.
Uniform laws were created for all citizens.
Internal custom duties and dues were abolished.
French Revolutionaries took it upon themselves to liberate other European countries and form nations.
The French armies were welcomed by European countries such as Holland, Belgium, Switzerland and Italy in the 1790s.
After the French Revolution, Napoleon Bonaparte emerged as the political leader of France.
Napoleon exploited the situation after the French revolution by conducting military campaigns in Europe and introduced the civil code or the Napoleonic code.  
Napoleonic Code
Privileges enjoyed by the noblemen and clergy on the basis of birth were abolished.
Equality before law and the right to property was secured.
The feudal system was abolished, and peasants were freed from serfdom and the payment dues to the manor owner.
Guild restrictions were removed, and the transport and communications systems were improved.
The businessmen and small producers realised that uniform laws, standardised weights and common national currency could facilitate free trade across Europe.
Countries that were brought under the French rule realised that they had lost their political freedom.
Higher taxes and forced enrolment of people into the French army overshadowed the positive administrative changes brought about by Napoleon.

snippet.title: CBSE Class 10 | History | Nationalism and Imperialism |
snippet.description:
In this module, you learn about, Nationalism and Imperialism, Through the 18th and the mid 19th century, Europe was marked by a lot of chaos and turmoil. 
After 1871, there was a significant change in the concept of nationalism in Europe.
Nationalist groups in Europe had become increasingly incompatible with each other and were constantly in conflict.
The major European powers began taking advantage of nationalism in Europe, to materialise their aims for imperialism.
Imperialism refers to the policy of extending the rule and the authority of an empire or nation over foreign countries, or of acquiring and holding colonies and dependencies.  
The European powers sighted the much-disturbed Balkans region to fulfil their imperialist goals.
The Balkans region was formed of the following countries of our times - Romania, Bulgaria, Albania, Greece, Macedonia, Croatia, Bosnia-Herzegovina, Slovenia, Serbia and Montenegro. 
People of different ethnicities and culture lived in the Balkans, and they were collectively known as Slavs.
The spread of romantic nationalism and the downfall of the Ottoman Empire had made the Balkans peninsula very tense and volatile.
The Ottoman Empire had not been able to strengthen itself even after having adopted reforms and modern methods.
The European subjects had begun to break away from the Ottoman Empire and had started declaring themselves independent.
The Balkans claimed independence and a separate political identity based on nationality. 
The Balkans argued that they had been dominated by foreign countries earlier so now they wanted to break away from the foreign rule and gain independence.
The Balkans were jealous of each other and wanted to expand control over each other’s territories.
Intensifying the tension was the rivalry between the European powers over trade, colonies, and naval and military strength.
To fulfil these aims, Russia, Germany, England and Austro-Hungary wanted to extend their control over the already disturbed Balkan region. Their rivalry caused many wars and culminated in the First World War.
Later, in the nineteenth century, the countries colonised by the European powers began to overthrow their imperial domination.
Many countries struggled for the formation of nation states and each country was inspired by a sense of collective national unity.
Every country developed its own specific nationalism; there was one thing in common - the idea of organising societies as nation states.

snippet.title: CBSE Class 10 | History | Revolutions of Liberals and Women |
snippet.description:
In this module, you learn about, Revolutions of Liberals and Women, The history of Europe between 1830 and 1848 was lined with many revolts and uprisings.
In Germany, Italy, Poland and the Austria-Hungary Empire, people of the liberal middle class began demanding a constitution and national unification.
On May 18, 1948, the Frankfurt Parliament was convened in the Church of Saint Paul by members elected from various political associations.
The members drafted a constitution based on the idea of a monarchy subject to parliament.
When the members requested Friedrich Wilhelm IV, King of Prussia, to accept the crown, he declined. 
The middle class dominated the parliament and did not give notice to the demands of artisans and peasants. 
The aristocracy, powered by the army, got the Frankfurt Parliament disbanded.
In Europe, the conservatives tried their best to suppress the liberal movements, but failed miserably.
The monarchs realised that the demands of liberals could no longer be ignored. 
After 1848, the autocratic monarchies of central and eastern Europe began to incorporate changes that had already taken place in western Europe.
Serfdom and bonded labour were abolished in the Habsburg Empire and Russia.
Since the French Revolution, women had actively participated in revolutions, but they never got their due.
They founded newspapers and political associations, yet they were not granted suffrage.
Famous political activist Louise Otto-Peters championed women rights
Liberal revolutionaries exhibited narrow mindedness in their attitude towards women.  
Carl Welcker, a member of the Frankfurt Parliament, had tremendous reservation against equal rights for women, and he ridiculed their demands as being against nature.
This awareness of women’s rights based on political and social equality of genders is also known as feminism.

snippet.title: CBSE Class 10 | History | Conservatism and Revolutionaries |
snippet.description:
In this module, you learn about, Conservatism and Revolutionaries, The autocratic governments of Europe adopted the idea of conservatism after Napoleon’s defeat in 1815.
Conservatism was a political philosophy that stressed the importance of tradition, established institutions and customs.
The representatives of European powers met at Vienna after Napoleon’s defeat; this meeting was known as the Treaty or Congress of Vienna.
After1815, several liberals began working in secret societies to propagate revolutionary ideas.
Screen Number
5
Section
Summary
On Screen Text
After Napoleon’s defeat in 1815, the autocratic governments of Europe adopted the idea of conservatism.
Conservatism was a political philosophy that stressed the importance of tradition, established institutions and customs.
The conservatives emphasised and preferred gradual development to quick change.
The conservatives wanted to retain the social and administrative changes brought about by Napoleon in order to strengthen the monarchy.
In 1815, the representatives of European powers met at Vienna after Napoleon’s defeat.
The meeting in Vienna is also known as the Treaty or Congress of Vienna.
The chief architect and host of the Treaty of Vienna was the Austrian Chancellor, Duke Metternich.
The following changes took place as per the treaty of Vienna:
The Bourbon dynasty was restored to power in France.
France lost most of the territories it had gained during Napoleon’s time.
To prevent the expansion of France in the future, certain states were set up along its borders. 
The kingdom of the Netherlands, including Belgium, was set up in the north of France.
Genoa was added to Piedmont in the south of France.
Russia was given a part of Poland, while Prussia was given a portion of Saxony.
The conservatives imposed censorship laws on newspapers, books, plays and songs as they championed freedom.
The liberals raised their voice against the censorship of the press and the autocratic monarchical structures.
After1815, several liberals began working in secret societies all over Europe to propagate revolutionary ideas.
Revolutionaries were seen as a threat to the restored monarchies, and hence, were repressed.
Giuseppe Mazzini was a famous Italian revolutionary born in 1807 in Genoa.
In 1831, Mazzini was sent into exile for attempting a revolution in Liguria.
Mazzini was a part of a secret society called Carbonari. He also founded two more underground societies called Young Italy in Marseilles, and Young Europe in Berne.
Mazzini believed in the unification of the small kingdoms and principalities in Italy.
Following Mazzini’s unification model, secret societies were set up in Germany, France, Switzerland and Poland as well.

snippet.title: CBSE Class 10 | History | The Rise of Nationalism in Europe |
snippet.description:
In this module, you learn about, The Rise of Nationalism in Europe, The concepts of liberty, equality, fraternity and nationalism dominated the social and political scene of Europe during the 19th century.
The first print by the French artist Frédéric Sorrieu depicted a utopian world made up of democratic and social republics.
Utopian vision refers to a vision of a society that is so ideal that it is unlikely to actually exist.
Absolutism refers to a system of rule with a lot of uncontrolled power; an oppressive monarchical government.
The middle class consisting  of industrialists, businessmen and professionals wanted to bring together people with a shared past, history and culture, which gave rise to the idea of nation states.
In the 19th century, the concept of nation states did not take into account the geographical boundary of a country.
Plebiscite is an important right given by a nation to its citizens.
A plebiscite is a direct vote by which the people of a region are asked to accept or reject a proposal.

snippet.title: CBSE Class 10 | History | Visualising a Nation |
snippet.description:
In this module, you learn about, Visualising a Nation, A symbol is a visual image that represents something other than itself.
 It may be a representation using an object, picture, written word, sound or a particular mark.
During the 18th and the 19th centuries, several symbols were used by artists and revolutionaries to depict abstract concepts.
Symbols were usually popular images from everyday life that uneducated masses could easily identify with.  
A Broken chain represented abolition of slavery.
A fasces or a bundle of rods with an axe in the middle was used to symbolise strength in unity. 
The red Phrygian cap signified freedom of a slave. It was also known as the liberty cap. French people wore these caps a few days before the storming of the Bastille.
During revolutions, artists represented nation as a person in order to put life into abstract concepts like a nation.
The way of expressing an abstract idea like freedom or liberty through a symbol that may be person or thing is known as allegory. An allegory has a literal and a symbolic meaning.
In the 19th century, French artists used the female allegory, Marianne, to represent France.
Marianne symbolises reason, liberty and the ideals of the republic
She wore a red cap and a knotted ribbon or cockade, and carried the French tricolour.
Statues of Marianne were erected in public squares to familiarize people with Marianne as the national symbol of unity.
Images of Marianne were used on coins and stamps.
In Germany, the allegory for nation was again a female figure called Germania.
She wears a crown of oak leaves, a symbol of heroism in Germany.
Germania wears a breastplate with an eagle, which is a symbol of German strength.
The black, red and gold tricolour in Germania’s hand is the flag of the liberal nationalists of 1848.
The sword in Germania’s hand is a symbol of her readiness to fight.
A flag is the symbol of unity and encourages people to be united.
The personification of a nation infused feelings of patriotism and nationalism in people.

snippet.title: CBSE Class 10 | History | Cities and the Challenges of the Environment |
snippet.description:
In this module, you learn about, Cities and the Challenges of the Environment, Most cities grew and developed at the expense to the environment. Natural features were cleared to make space for factories, houses, business, schools, etc.
Urban development led to air, water and noise pollution, which became a regular feature of urban life. 
Industrial cities such as Leeds, Bradford and Manchester were covered with thick black fog or smog throughout the day.
This smog posed serious health and environmental problems. 
Although people campaigned for cleaner air, businesses were unwilling to invest in technology that would improve their machines and reduce pollution.
Calcutta suffered from air pollution caused by the fog emanating from its marshes mixed with the smoke from burnt dung and wood that was used as fuel in daily life.
It became the first Indian city to get smoke nuisance legislation.

snippet.title: CBSE Class 10 | History | Social change and Politics in the City |
snippet.description:
In this module, you learn about, Social change and Politics in the City, Industrialisation brought many people to the city, in search of a better life. 
The city encouraged a spirit of individualism. 
The term Individualism refers to a theory which promotes the liberty, rights or independent action of the individual, rather than of the community.
However, individualism did not offer equal rights to men and women. 
Political movements such as Chartism, the 10-hour movement, focussed solely on the rights of men. The later women suffrages movements made people aware of the rights of women to vote and own property.
Families became smaller and people had more time for leisure. 
Rich people visited pleasure gardens equipped with sports facilities, entertainment and refreshments. 
The State sponsored libraries, art galleries and museums, for the working classes, to educate, to entertain and to instil a sense of pride in people.
Cinema became the new form of mass entertainment.
Groups of people could be drawn into political causes. For instance, the riots of 1886, the Bloody Sunday riots and the 12-day dockyard union’s strike. 
State authorities tried to keep rebellion in check by enhancing the beauty of urban areas. 
Haussmanisation refers to the forcible reconstruction of cities to enhance their beauty and impose order. It displaced approximately 350,000 people from the centre of Paris.
Initially criticised as boring, Haussman’s redesigning of Paris was later appreciated by people all over the world.

snippet.title: CBSE Class 10 | History | The City of Bombay |
snippet.description:
In this module, you learn about, The City of Bombay, Bombay was a group of seven islands under Portuguese control. 
It became the base and principal western port of the British East India Company.
Bombay functioned as an important port for trade in cotton and opium and thus attracted communities of traders and merchants. 
Its sugar and textile mills drew in migrant workers.
Bombay was at the junction head of two major railways. This further encouraged the migration of people to they city. 
The influx of people soon created a crisis of housing space and water supply.
The majority of the working population lived in the thickly populated chawls.
Life in the city was often authentically captured by the Bombay Film Industry.
Reclaiming land from the sea was one way in which the authorities tried to solve the space crunch. 
A good example of this reclamation activity is the famous Marine Drive.

snippet.title: CBSE Class 10 | History | The City of London |
snippet.description:
In this module, you learn about, The City of London, After the Industrial revolution, London’s population increased from 675,000 in 1750 to about 4 million in 1880.
The city gradually underwent urbanisation as people migrated to it for work.
People sought work in the London dockyard, and in other industries.
During this period, the workforce comprised of men, women and children. It was only after the passing of the Compulsory Elementary Education Act that children were kept out of industrial work.
The growing population of London caused concern for the police, philanthropists, and Industrialists..
Many women lost their jobs thanks to technological developments.
London faced a severe housing shortage and migrant workers began to live in tenements. 
Three major concerns that led to better housing for the poor were: the threat to public health, the possibility of fire hazards and the fear of social disorder.
The London Underground was built to ease the housing shortage and help people commute to work.
The Underground was criticised as it was thought to add to the mess and unhealthiness of the city.
Its construction had caused the destruction of several houses, leading to a massive displacement of the poor.
